questions.question: I wouldn't .................................. a loan.
questions.description: After advise, we use an ing form, if there is no object. If there is an object, we use an infinitive.

questions.question: We don't allow ......................... in the kitchen.
questions.description: After allow we use an ing form if there is no object. If there is an object, we use an infinitive.

questions.question: Guests are not allowed ............................ in the kitchen.
We are proud ................................
questions.description: The adjective proud can be followed by either an -ing form or an infinitive.

questions.question: I tried ..................... the wheel, but my hands were stiff.
questions.description: After try, we can use either an infinitive or an -ing form.

questions.question: I would like .............................. you something.
questions.description: After would like, we use infinitives.

questions.question: Do you like .............................?
questions.description: We use an -ing form after like to make a general statement or to ask a general question about preferences.

questions.question: I slowly began ................................. what she said.
questions.description: The verbs understand, realise and know are not normally used in the continuous form.

questions.question: I am sorry .................................. my temper this morning.
questions.description: Sorry about + ing is used to refer to past things one regrets.

questions.question: I am not afraid ............................... the truth.
questions.description: There is little or no difference between afraid of + ing or afraid + infinitive.

questions.question: Sorry ............................ you waiting. We can start now.
questions.description: Sorry + infinitive is used to apologize for current situations.

questions.question: I hate .............................. on weekends.
questions.description: After hate, both infinitives and ing forms can be used.
